content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Excellent flare. I would introduce it in companies to warm up employees

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This challenge was fun. I even tested it with reverse mode and that seems reasonable.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

good job.
i think is more fun if each user have a starting money.

As others have commented, it is both interesting as well as slightly on the challenging side for a clash. What partly makes it challenging is that there is a lot to read. Maybe you could resolve this by making the example (firs test case) *very easy*: with easy numbers and not yet overlapping sender&receiver. Then a player can choose to read, or get the idea from the example right away. (So, I would propose to also add the $ in the input - it makes the required coding slightly harder but the Example will be so clear that players can start coding right away)
Something like:
2
Bitcoin 25000.00$
Ethereum 5000.00$
2
Alice Bob 1.0 Bitcoin
Charlie Bob 2.0 Ethereum
-> Alice -25000.00$; Bob 35000.00$; Charlie -10000.00$

The fact that someone can be both receiver and sender can be discovered in the later test cases, and will make the necessary solution code not much harder, so it is not a big loss to leave that away from the Example in my opinion.

Input section
* In the second description, please mention that exchange rate is a positive decimal number.

* For simplicity, please change:
   • "Lines 2 to C+1" to "Next [[C]] lines"
   • "Line C+2" to "Next line"
   • "Lines C+3 to C+T+2" to "Next [[T]] lines"

Input / Constraints sections
* For consistency with the stub generator, please change:
   • [[C]] to [[numberOfCurrencies]]
   • [[T]] to [[numberOfTransactions]]

Output section
* You may simplify "two digits after the decimal point" to "two decimal places".

Stub generator
* Suggest to provide parsed strings as much as possible, so that the players can focus on writing code to solve the main problem instead of parsing. So, e.g. you may change
   • line 2 to "loop numberOfCurrencies read currency:string(20) exchangeRate:float"
   • line 4 to "loop numberOfTransactions read user1:string(20) user2:string(20) amount:float currency:string(20)"

General
* More accurately speaking, the output is not really the final balance, as the opening balances are not taken into account in the calculation. The output is just the "net changes in the balances". But of course, including the opening balances will mean the clash is even more complex (and it already is). It's easier to think that the current clash assumes the opening balances are zero for everyone (and the users are able to pay out of nothingness, lol).

Thanks.

Seems quite difficult for an clash, but also interesting. 

I would suggest to modify one test case, which contains a conversion for a cryptocurrency which isn't used in a transaction.
Addition of an "$" to the output is possible. It would emphasis the converion

Might be clear enough, but it could be beneficial to clarify that users are senders as well as receivers.

Thank you Grossieb for your comment.
I added a "$" after balances to outputs.

Indeed, the statement could be simplified for a CoC.
For example, I could remove the conversion + cryptocurrencies part. Sojust keep a list of transactions + calculate each user's balance.
But the exercise would be somewhat stripped of its substance.

I am open to other feedback. If other reviewers agree with your point of view, I will modify the statement according to :)

TY very much for your feedback. I normally took them into account.

I join you in your comment "General".
Even with parsed strings in the stub, not having the opening balance can be confusing for players. I'm talking about ending balances, when it comes to net changes in balances.

Maybe it would be better to rewrite the exercice, adding an opening balance, but turning this CoC into an easy Puzzle.
An additional idea could be that a user cannot have a negative balance after a transaction.
If this case happens, ask to print IMPOSSIBLE (because magic money does not exist in this simulation :))

Thanks! I made the adjustments. 
Indeed, by making the first test case readable, the players should rather quickly understand what is expected

Actually with some tweaks this might indeed be nice as an easy puzzle. Some ideas:
- The IMPOSSIBLE case could become interesting if it would also influence transactions later in the list (or, the other way around, that a player must order the transactions in such a way that as much as possible of the transactions become possible)
- Adding a "[[user1]]=None [[user2]]=some name" mimicking cash influx (e.g. 'None Alice 50000 Dollar': Alice getting some extra money on her balance simply by giving herself actual dollars)
- Some transactions organized like 'the number of bitcoins equaling 1000 $' (eg Bob Alice X Bitcoin 1000)
Wouldn't remove the conversion and crypto part. I do like it that the task stems from a certain domain.

Great, looking forward to more reviews.
By the way, I updated the "Unused Cryptos" test/validator which contains a conversion for a cryptocurrency that is not used in a transaction.
I also specify in the constraints section that a user can be the sender in one transaction and the receiver in another.
